questions.text: Which of the following can be used for induction of anesthesia, maintenance and can be safely used in endotracheal intubation?
questions.solution:
Ans. C. Sevoflurane

 

Explanation:

 

Sevoflurane is a versatile inhalation anesthetic that can be used for both the induction and maintenance of anesthesia. Its sweet smell makes it suitable for inhalational induction, especially in pediatric patients and others who might find pungent agents unpleasant. Sevoflurane also provides a smooth transition for endotracheal intubation due to its bronchodilatory effects and stable hemodynamic profile. Additionally, its low blood-gas solubility coefficient allows for rapid induction and emergence from anesthesia, which is beneficial in a surgical setting.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Halothane: While Halothane can be used for induction and maintenance of anesthesia, it has a higher risk of hepatotoxicity and arrhythmias. It is also less commonly used in modern practice compared to Sevoflurane.

 

Option B. Desflurane: Desflurane is typically used for maintenance rather than induction due to its pungent odor and tendency to cause airway irritation. It also requires a special heated vaporizer due to its high vapor pressure.

 

Option D. Isoflurane: Isoflurane is primarily used for maintenance of anesthesia rather than induction due to its pungent smell and potential to cause airway irritation. It is less suitable for inhalational induction compared to Sevoflurane.

 

Educational Objective :

 

Sevoflurane is an ideal agent for both the induction and maintenance of anesthesia and is safe for use during endotracheal intubation due to its favorable properties.

questions.text: A 60 years old male patient was undergoing laparoscopic cholecystectomy. During the surgery, it was observed that there was a sudden decrease in etCO2  to 8 mm Hg, SpO2 was 90%, BP dropped to 80/50 mm Hg and peak airway pressure was observed to be 18 mm Hg. Which of the most probable diagnosis? (INICET Nov 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. B. CO2 embolism

 

Explanation:

 

In the scenario described, a sudden decrease in end-tidal CO2 (etCO2) to 8 mm Hg, along with a drop in blood pressure (BP) to 80/50 mm Hg and oxygen saturation (SpO2) to 90%, but with normal peak airway pressure (18 mm Hg), strongly suggests a CO2 embolism. During laparoscopic procedures, CO2 is used for insufflation to create a pneumoperitoneum, which can occasionally enter a blood vessel and cause a CO2 embolism. This event leads to a rapid decrease in etCO2 due to reduced return of CO2 to the lungs, hypoxemia, and cardiovascular collapse. The normal peak airway pressures help differentiate it from other causes of acute respiratory distress.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Pneumothorax: A pneumothorax, or collapsed lung, could occur due to barotrauma from mechanical ventilation or surgical complications. However, it typically causes an increase in peak airway pressures due to increased resistance to ventilation. The absence of increased peak airway pressures makes pneumothorax less likely in this case.

 

Option C. Endobronchial Intubation: Endobronchial intubation occurs when the endotracheal tube is inserted too far and intubates one of the main bronchi, typically the right main bronchus. This can lead to hypoventilation of one lung, causing a decrease in etCO2 and SpO2. However, peak airway pressures might be higher due to one-lung ventilation, which was not observed here.

 

Option D. Bronchospasm: Bronchospasm involves the constriction of the muscles in the walls of the bronchioles, leading to narrowed airways. This would usually present with an increase in peak airway pressures due to the narrowed airways, which is not consistent with the normal peak airway pressures reported in this scenario.

 

Educational Objective:

 

During laparoscopic surgery, the sudden onset of hypotension, hypoxemia, and a significant decrease in etCO2 with normal peak airway pressures suggests a CO2 embolism, a rare but potentially life-threatening complication.

questions.text: IV anesthetic agent that causes adrenocortical suppression is: (INICET NOV 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Etomidate

 

Etomidate causes adrenocortical suppression by inhibiting the 11-beta hydroxylase enzyme in the adrenal cortex. This enzyme is responsible for steroid production in the body. When etomidate inhibits this enzyme, it reduces steroid production, which can lead to adrenocortical suppression. Due to this effect, etomidate should be avoided in critically ill or septic patients where maintaining adequate steroid levels is important for hemodynamic stability.

 

Other Options: 

 

Option A. Propofol: Does not cause adrenocortical suppression. It acts mainly through GABA receptors and affects the central nervous system.

 

Option C. Thiopentone: A barbiturate that acts on GABA receptors but does not affect adrenal function or steroid synthesis.

 

Option D. Ketamine: An NMDA receptor antagonist that actually stimulates the sympathetic system and may increase steroid levels rather than suppress them.

 

Educational Objective: 

 

Etomidate causes adrenocortical suppression by inhibiting 11-beta hydroxylase enzyme in the adrenal cortex, making it unsuitable for use in critically ill or septic patients who require normal steroid function.

choices.text: Unconscious with Pulse present Breathing present
Conscious with Pulse present Breathing present

questions.text: This position is given in which patients? (NEET PG 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Unconscious with Pulse present Breathing present

 

The position shown in the image is the recovery position. This position is used for unconscious patients who have a pulse and are breathing adequately. The purpose of placing a patient in the recovery position is to maintain a clear airway and prevent aspiration by allowing any fluids (like saliva or vomit) to drain from the mouth. This position also helps prevent the tongue from obstructing the airway.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Pulse absent, Breathing present: If a patient is pulseless, they are in cardiac arrest and require immediate CPR, not placement in the recovery position.

 

Option B. Pulse absent, Breathing absent: In the absence of both pulse and breathing, the patient requires immediate CPR and advanced life support, not the recovery position.

 

Option D. Conscious with Pulse present, Breathing present: A conscious patient who is breathing and has a pulse would not need to be placed in the recovery position. They should be kept comfortable and monitored, but no special positioning is necessary unless they become unconscious.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The recovery position is used for unconscious patients who have a pulse and are breathing, to maintain airway patency and prevent aspiration.

questions.text: Nerve fibre least susceptible to local anaesthetic is? (AIIMS Nov 2017)
questions.solution:
Ans. D. C fibres

 

Explanation:

 

The nerve fibre least susceptible to local anaesthetic is type C. Local anaesthetics work by blocking sodium channels, which prevents the initiation and propagation of action potentials in nerves. The effectiveness of local anaesthetics depends on the diameter and myelination of the nerve fibres.

 

Type C fibres are unmyelinated and have the smallest diameter, making them the least susceptible to local anaesthetics. This means they require a higher concentration of the anaesthetic to achieve the same level of blockade as larger, myelinated fibres.

 

The order of susceptibility of nerve fibres to local anaesthetics is:

 

B > A-d > A-g > A-b > A-a > C

 

  • Nerve fibres most susceptible to local anesthetic: B fibres

  • Nerve fibres most resistant to local anesthetic: C fibres

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. A-delta: These are myelinated fibres with a small diameter, making them more susceptible to local anaesthetics compared to C fibres but less susceptible than larger, myelinated fibres like A-beta and A-alpha.

 

Option B. A-gamma: These are myelinated fibres with a moderate diameter, making them more susceptible to local anaesthetics compared to A-delta fibres but less susceptible than A-beta and A-alpha fibres.

 

Option C. A-beta: These are myelinated fibres with a larger diameter, making them more susceptible to local anaesthetics compared to A-delta and A-gamma fibres.

 

Educational Objective :

 

Type C nerve fibres are the least susceptible to local anaesthetics due to their small diameter and lack of myelination.

 

Ref: Miller’s Anesthesia, 9th Ed. Pgs 1416-1417

questions.text: Which of the following is measured by the device shown in the given image?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Oxygen saturation

 

  • Oxygen saturation (often referred to as SpO2) is the percentage of oxygen-saturated hemoglobin relative to the total hemoglobin (unsaturated + saturated) in the blood.
  • The device measures this by non-invasively detecting the color change in blood as it binds oxygen.
  • The image displays a reading of "98%", which is consistent with an SpO2 reading. Thus, this option is correct.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Oxygen content of the blood:

 

  • This refers to the amount of oxygen bound to hemoglobin in the blood plus any oxygen dissolved directly in the blood.
  • Pulse oximeters do not measure the total oxygen content of the blood. They only measure the percentage of oxygen-saturated hemoglobin.

 

Option C. Partial pressure of oxygen:

 

  • Partial pressure of oxygen (often referred to as PaO2) is the pressure exerted by oxygen in the blood. It's typically measured using an arterial blood gas analysis.
  • Pulse oximeters do not measure PaO2.

 

Option D. Amount of inspired oxygen:

 

  • This refers to the concentration of oxygen that a person is inhaling, often given as a percentage or fraction (FiO2).
  • Pulse oximeters do not measure the amount of inspired oxygen.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Pulse oximetry measures the oxygen saturation (SpO2) of hemoglobin in the blood using the principles of Beer Lambert’s law and plethysmography.

questions.text: The maximum oxygen flow rate which can be kept with a conventional Hudson oxygen mask is?
questions.solution:
Ans. C. 10 L/min

 

Explanation:

 

The maximum oxygen flow rate which can be kept with a conventional oxygen mask (Simple Face Mask, also known as Hudson mask) is 10 L/min. This is a standard setting for delivering oxygen to patients who require moderate levels of oxygen supplementation.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. 5 L/min: While 5 L/min can be used, it is not the maximum flow rate for a Hudson mask.

 

Option B. 15 L/min: This flow rate is generally used with a non-rebreather mask rather than a conventional Hudson mask.

 

Option D. 20 L/min: This flow rate exceeds the capacity of most conventional oxygen delivery systems like the Hudson mask.

 

Educational Objective :

 

The maximum flow rate for a conventional Hudson oxygen mask is 10 L/min.

questions.text: A patient was undergoing surgery under general anesthesia. For intubation, 90 mg of rocuronium was given, but the anesthesiologist was unable to intubate the patient. What is the drug given for immediate reversal of the neuromuscular blockade? (INICET MAY 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Sugammadex

 

Sugammadex is specifically designed to reverse the effects of rocuronium and vecuronium, which are non-depolarizing neuromuscular blocking agents used during anesthesia. Rocuronium works by blocking acetylcholine at the neuromuscular junction, leading to muscle paralysis. Sugammadex, a γ-cyclodextrin compound, encapsulates the rocuronium molecules, effectively removing them from the neuromuscular junction. This action results in the immediate reversal of muscle paralysis, allowing the patient to regain normal muscle function. Sugammadex is unique because it can rapidly reverse the effects of rocuronium, even if the drug was administered only moments earlier, which is crucial in situations where intubation fails and the patient needs to recover quickly.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Neostigmine: Neostigmine is used to reverse non-depolarizing neuromuscular blockers like rocuronium, but it is not effective immediately after the drug has been administered. Neostigmine works by inhibiting acetylcholinesterase, thereby increasing acetylcholine levels at the neuromuscular junction to outcompete the blocking agent. However, for neostigmine to be effective, a significant amount of the neuromuscular blocking agent must have already dissociated from the receptors, which typically happens toward the end of the surgery, not immediately after administration.

 

Option C. Glycopyrrolate: Glycopyrrolate is often used in conjunction with neostigmine to counteract the muscarinic side effects of increased acetylcholine, such as bradycardia. However, glycopyrrolate itself does not reverse neuromuscular blockade and cannot be used to immediately counteract the effects of rocuronium.

 

Option D. Atropine: Atropine, like glycopyrrolate, is used to mitigate the side effects of cholinesterase inhibitors like neostigmine. It does not reverse neuromuscular blockade directly and is not effective in immediately reversing the effects of rocuronium.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Sugammadex is the specific and immediate antidote for the reversal of rocuronium-induced neuromuscular blockade. It is unique in its ability to rapidly and effectively reverse paralysis even shortly after rocuronium administration, making it the drug of choice in emergency situations where rapid recovery of muscle function is required.

questions.text: At what level does the spinal cord end in adults? (AIIMS May 2018)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) L1-L2

 

Explanation:

 

Termination of the Spinal Cord:

 

  • Anatomy: The spinal cord terminates at a region called the conus medullaris.
  • Details: Below the conus medullaris, a bundle of spinal nerve roots continues downward, which is called the cauda equina (meaning "horse's tail" in Latin) due to its appearance.
  • Adult Spinal Cord End: The lower end of the spinal cord in adults is at the lower border of L1.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. L3-L4: This is incorrect as the spinal cord in adults does not extend to this level. This level is generally where lumbar punctures are performed to avoid the spinal cord.

 

Option C. T12-L1: This is slightly higher than the actual end of the spinal cord in adults. The spinal cord terminates at L1-L2, not T12-L1.

 

Option D. L2-L3: This is incorrect as well because the spinal cord ends at L1-L2 in adults, not extending to L2-L3.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • The spinal cord in adults terminates at the lower border of L1, at the region called the conus medullaris, with the cauda equina continuing downward from this point.

 

Ref: Miller’s Anesthesia, 9th Ed. Pg 1414

questions.text: In conventional oxygen therapy, which device will deliver the highest FiO2? (INICET May 2021)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Non-rebreathing mask

 

  • FiO2 Delivery: A non-rebreathing mask can deliver an FiO2 of up to 80% at flow rates of 10-15 L/min. This mask has a reservoir bag that fills with oxygen and a one-way valve that prevents the exhaled air from entering the reservoir bag, ensuring a higher concentration of oxygen is inhaled.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Venturi mask: The Venturi mask delivers a precise FiO2, which can range from 24% to 66%, depending on the entrainment device used. It is often used in patients who require a specific oxygen concentration.

 

Option B. Hudson mask: This option appears to refer to a simple face mask, which can deliver up to 60% FiO2 at 10 L/min. It is less efficient in delivering high concentrations of oxygen compared to a non-rebreathing mask.

 

Option D. Nasal cannula: A nasal cannula typically delivers up to 44% FiO2 at a flow rate of 6 L/min. It is comfortable and used for patients who need low to moderate oxygen supplementation but cannot deliver the high concentrations achievable with a non-rebreathing mask.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • The non-rebreathing mask delivers the highest FiO2 in conventional oxygen therapy, capable of providing up to 80% FiO2 at flow rates of 10-15 L/min, making it suitable for patients requiring high concentrations of oxygen.

choices.text: Preoxygenation with 100% oxygen for 3 minutes is done.
High-volume low-pressure cuff Endotracheal tube is used.
It is the method of choice in cardiac arrest patients.
Induction agent and muscle relaxant are given simultaneously.

questions.text: Identify the incorrect statement in rapid sequence intubation? (INICET NOVEMBER 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. C. It is the method of choice in cardiac arrest patients.


Incorrect statement. Rapid sequence intubation typically involves administering an induction agent and a neuromuscular blocking agent to facilitate endotracheal intubation without the risk of aspiration. However, in cardiac arrest patients, the priority is to secure the airway quickly without delay. Often, these patients do not require medications for intubation as they are unresponsive and without protective reflexes. Also, chest compressions and defibrillation (if indicated) are of higher priority.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Preoxygenation with 100% oxygen for 3 minutes is done:
Correct statement. Preoxygenation with 100% oxygen before RSI helps to denitrogenate the lungs, ensuring that the patient has an adequate oxygen reserve during the apneic period (the time between paralysis and successful intubation). The goal is to delay the onset of hypoxemia during the apnea.

 

Option B. High-volume low-pressure cuff Endotracheal tube is used:
Correct statement. A high-volume low-pressure cuff on the endotracheal tube distributes the pressure over a larger area of the tracheal mucosa. This minimizes the risk of tracheal injury or necrosis.

 

Option D. Induction agent and muscle relaxant are given simultaneously:
Correct statement. In RSI, immediately after administering the induction agent (to render the patient unconscious), a neuromuscular blocking agent (muscle relaxant) is given to paralyze the patient, thus facilitating endotracheal intubation. This rapid administration of drugs is to minimize the time between loss of protective reflexes and securing the airway, hence reducing the risk of aspiration.

 

Educational Objective :

 

Rapid sequence intubation is not the method of choice in cardiac arrest patients due to the need for immediate airway management and ongoing chest compressions, making drug administration less critical.

questions.text: A patient undergoing surgery is maintained on anesthesia with halothane. During the procedure, the patient suddenly developed hyperthermia and muscle rigidity. Which of the following drugs is most likely implicated in this condition? (NEET PG 2021)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Suxamethonium

 

The scenario described involves a patient undergoing surgery who suddenly develops hyperthermia and muscle rigidity. This is indicative of a condition called Malignant Hyperthermia (MH), which is a rare but potentially life-threatening reaction to certain medications used during anesthesia.

 

In this case, the most likely drug implicated in causing MH is:

 

Suxamethonium (also known as succinylcholine)

 

  • Suxamethonium is a depolarizing neuromuscular blocking agent commonly used for muscle relaxation during surgery.
  • However, it is known to be associated with triggering malignant hyperthermia in susceptible individuals.
  • MH is a severe reaction that can cause a rapid increase in body temperature, muscle rigidity, and other complications.

 

Other Options :

 

Option A. Doxacurium: Doxacurium is a non-depolarizing neuromuscular blocking agent used to induce muscle relaxation during surgery. It is not typically associated with causing malignant hyperthermia.

 

Option C. Atracurium: Atracurium is another non-depolarizing neuromuscular blocking agent used in anesthesia. It is not typically associated with causing malignant hyperthermia.

 

Option D. Rocuronium: Rocuronium is also a non-depolarizing neuromuscular blocking agent. Like atracurium and doxacurium, it is not typically associated with causing malignant hyperthermia.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • The drug most likely implicated in causing malignant hyperthermia in the given scenario is suxamethonium (succinylcholine) because it is known to trigger this condition in susceptible individuals.

 

Treatment - Dantrolene sodium and supportive management

choices.text: 1 min
3 min
5-7 min
5 min

questions.text: The time required for preoxygenation before tracheal intubation is?(AIIMS NOV 2017)
questions.solution:
Ans. B. 3 min

 

Explanation:

 

Preoxygenation or denitrogenation is the process of replacing nitrogen in the lungs with oxygen. This is typically done by giving 100% oxygen to the patient for 3 minutes through a tight-fitting mask or by asking them to take 8 vital capacity breaths. This process helps to lengthen the apnea time, providing an improved margin of safety while the anesthesiologist secures the airway and resumes ventilation.

 

There are two main methods commonly used for preoxygenation:

 

  1. The first method involves utilizing tidal volume ventilation through a face mask for a duration of 3 minutes. This technique allows for the exchange of approximately 95% of the gas present in the lungs.
  2. The second method relies on vital capacity breaths to achieve effective preoxygenation in a shorter time frame. While four breaths over 30 seconds are not as efficient as the tidal volume method, it may still be deemed acceptable in specific clinical scenarios. Research has indicated that eight breaths over a span of 60 seconds are more effective for preoxygenation.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. 1 min: This duration is insufficient for effective preoxygenation, as it does not allow adequate time to replace the nitrogen in the lungs with oxygen.

 

Option C. 5-7 min: While longer preoxygenation can ensure thorough denitrogenation, it is not typically necessary beyond the 3 minutes required for effective preoxygenation.

 

Option D. 5 min: Preoxygenation for this duration can be effective, but the standard practice is to use 3 minutes as it is usually sufficient to achieve the desired effect.

 

Educational Objective :

 

Preoxygenation for tracheal intubation is effectively achieved by administering 100% oxygen for 3 minutes through a tight-fitting mask or by taking 8 vital capacity breaths.

 

Ref: Miller’s Anesthesia, 9th Ed. Pg 1380

choices.text: Increase flow rate to 15 L/min
High-flow nasal cannula oxygen therapy

questions.text: A 40-year-old man who was under home isolation after testing positive for COVID-19, develops breathing difficulty and is brought to the ER. The patient is alert and responsive, but his respiratory rate is 26/min. Room air Sp02 is 86%. He is administered oxygen through a non -rebreathing mask with a flow rate of 10 L/ min. After a trial of one hour, his SpO2 is 88%. What is the next step in management?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) High-flow nasal cannula oxygen therapy

 

  • Mechanism of Action: HFNC can deliver warmed, humidified oxygen at high flow rates (up to 60 L/min or more), creating a positive end-expiratory pressure (PEEP) effect, reducing nasopharyngeal dead space, and improving oxygenation.
  • Effectiveness: Studies have shown its effectiveness in treating acute hypoxemic respiratory failure in COVID-19 patients. Given that the patient's SpO2 didn't improve significantly with an NRB, transitioning to HFNC might be a logical step before considering more invasive measures like intubation.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Increase flow rate to 15 L/min: The non-rebreather mask (NRB) is designed to deliver high concentrations of oxygen (up to 90%). Increasing the flow rate may slightly improve the fraction of delivered oxygen, but it may not result in significant improvement in oxygenation, especially if the cause of hypoxia isn't just a low FiO2. Therefore, merely increasing the flow rate may not be sufficient to address the patient's respiratory distress.

 

Option C. Endotracheal intubation: Endotracheal intubation and mechanical ventilation are invasive interventions, reserved for patients who are in respiratory failure and cannot maintain adequate oxygenation and/or ventilation with less invasive means. While this patient is hypoxic, jumping straight to intubation without trialing intermediate steps like HFNC might be premature, especially since the patient is alert and responsive.

 

Option D. No specific intervention necessary: Given the patient's low SpO2 and increased respiratory rate, no intervention is not an appropriate choice. The patient is in respiratory distress and requires further measures to improve his oxygenation.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • In a patient with COVID-19 and hypoxemia unresponsive to a non-rebreather mask, transitioning to high-flow nasal cannula oxygen therapy (HFNC) is a logical next step. HFNC can provide better oxygenation and is a less invasive option before considering endotracheal intubation.

choices.text: Check carotid pulse, start CPR, and call for help, Defibrillate if no pulse.
Call for help, check pulse, do CPR, defibrillate if no pulse

questions.text: On your evening walk in the park, you notice an unconscious man lying on the ground. What would you do next? (INICET Nov 2020)
questions.solution:
Ans. B. Call for help, check pulse, do CPR, defibrillate if no pulse

 

Explanation:

 

Call for help, check pulse, do CPR, defibrillate if no pulse: This is the recommended sequence in most bystander situations. Firstly, ensure scene safety (make sure you're not putting yourself or the individual in further danger). Then, call for help or ask someone nearby to do so. This ensures that professional medical help is on the way. After calling for help, you’d check the pulse and breathing. If the person is not breathing and/or doesn’t have a pulse, you would start CPR. If an Automated External Defibrillator (AED) is available and the person doesn’t have a pulse, you would use it as soon as possible.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Check carotid pulse, start CPR, and call for help, Defibrillate if no pulse: While checking the pulse and starting CPR is correct, calling for help first ensures that professional medical assistance is on the way, which is crucial for the best chance of survival.

 

Option C. Observe: This is not the recommended approach. Immediate intervention is critical when someone is unconscious, especially if they are not breathing or lack a pulse. Delays in initiating CPR or calling for help can drastically reduce the chance of survival and increase the potential for permanent injury.

 

Option D. Ignore and continue to walk: This is not an ethical or appropriate response when encountering someone in potential distress. Immediate action can make the difference between life and death.

 

Educational Objective :

 

In an emergency situation where someone is unconscious, the immediate steps should be to call for help, check for a pulse and breathing, start CPR if needed, and use a defibrillator if available and the person has no pulse.

 

Ref: Miller’s Anesthesia, 9th Ed. Pgs 2715-2716

questions.text: Identify the maneuver being performed in the given image? (NEET PG 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Head tilt, chin lift

 

The maneuver performed in the given image is that of a head-tilt chin-lift. It is an important technique in emergency airway management to open up the airway.

 

  • Tilt the patient’s head back by pushing down on the forehead.
  • Place the tips of your index and middle fingers under the chin and pull up on the mandible (not on the soft tissues). This lifts the tongue away from the posterior pharynx and improves airway patency.

 

There is no absolute contraindication to it but Suspected cervical injury is a relative contraindication.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Jaw thrust: Lift the mandible upward with your fingers, at least until the lower incisors are higher than the upper incisors. This maneuver lifts the tongue along with the mandible, thus relieving upper airway obstruction.

 

 

Option D. Manual inline stabilization: is a neck immobilisation technique in a natural position achieved by using the fingers and palms of both hands to stabilize the patient's occiput and mastoid processes to gently counteract the forces of airway intervention

 

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • The head-tilt chin-lift maneuver is a key technique for opening the airway in emergency situations, especially when cervical spine injury is not suspected.

questions.text: What does phase III represent in the below image? (NEET PG 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Alveolar plateau

 

The image represents a capnography waveform, which displays the concentration of carbon dioxide (CO2) in exhaled air. Phase III of the capnography waveform, also known as the alveolar plateau, represents the period during exhalation where CO2 levels plateau as alveolar gas is exhaled. This phase reflects the CO2 concentration from the alveoli, which is relatively stable until the end of expiration. The end of phase III corresponds to the end-tidal CO2 (EtCO2), a key measurement in monitoring ventilation.

 

 

Educational Objective:

 

Phase III of the capnography waveform, also known as the alveolar plateau, represents the exhalation of alveolar gas and is used to determine the end-tidal CO2 level.

choices.text: It achieves maximum concentration in brain after IV infusion
Redistribution to adipose tissue and muscle is seen
The rapid decline in its effect is due to renal excretion

questions.text: Which of these statements is incorrect about Thiopentone? (INICET NOV 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) The rapid decline in its effect is due to renal excretion

 

The rapid decline in thiopentone's effect is due to redistribution, not renal excretion. Thiopentone's ultra-short acting nature is due to:

 

  • Initial high concentration in brain due to high lipid solubility
  • Subsequent redistribution from brain to less perfused tissues like muscle and fat
  • This redistribution causes rapid decline in brain concentration leading to awakening
  • Continuous redistribution between highly perfused and less perfused lipid-soluble areas maintains this pattern
  • The process is independent of renal excretion

 

Other Options: 

 

Option A. It is highly lipid soluble: Correct statement. This property allows rapid crossing of blood-brain barrier.

 

Option B. It achieves maximum concentration in brain after IV infusion: Correct statement. Due to brain being highly perfused and thiopentone's lipid solubility.

 

Option C. Redistribution to adipose tissue and muscle is seen: Correct statement. This is the key mechanism for its short duration of action.

 

Educational Objective: 

 

The rapid decline in thiopentone's anesthetic effect is due to redistribution to less perfused tissues, not renal excretion, explaining its ultra-short acting nature.

 

THIOPENTONE

 

  • T - Thiobarbiturates
  • H - Hyperthyroidism
  • I - Inadvertent intra-arterial Injection causes vasospasm (treatment - flush with NS, heparin, lignocaine)
  • O - pH 10.5 (alkaline)
  • P - pH
  • Porphyrias (C/I)
  • Prolongation of QT interval
  • E - Epilepsy
  • N - Neuroanesthesia (DOC)
  • T - Termination of action - redistribution

questions.text: A patient is given a nicotinic receptor antagonist as a muscle relaxant. Which drug is given postoperatively to recover from muscle weakness? (NEET PG 2020)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Neostigmine

 

For reversal of neuromuscular blockade from non-depolarizing muscle relaxants, the reversal agent of choice is Neostigmine.

 

  • Neostigmine is a cholinesterase inhibitor that boosts the concentration of acetylcholine in the neuromuscular junction, thus enhancing muscle contraction.
  • Neostigmine is the drug of choice for reversing the effects of non-depolarizing muscle relaxants postoperatively. By preventing the breakdown of acetylcholine, it counteracts the muscle-relaxing effects of these drugs.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Physostigmine:

 

  • Physostigmine is a reversible cholinesterase inhibitor. It increases the concentration of acetylcholine at nerve endings.
  • Physostigmine is primarily used to treat anticholinergic (atropine-like) drug overdoses. It can cross the blood-brain barrier and is used for central anticholinergic syndromes. It is not typically used for reversing neuromuscular blockade from muscle relaxants.

 

Option C. Carbachol:

 

  • Carbachol is a cholinergic drug that acts as an agonist at both muscarinic and nicotinic receptors.
  • Carbachol is primarily used in ophthalmology to induce miosis or to reduce intraocular pressure. It is not used for reversing neuromuscular blockade.

 

Option D. Succinylcholine:

 

  • Succinylcholine is a depolarizing neuromuscular blocker. It binds to nicotinic receptors and causes prolonged depolarization, which initially causes muscle fasciculation followed by paralysis.
  • Succinylcholine itself causes muscle paralysis and is used to facilitate intubation during anesthesia induction. It would not be used to reverse muscle relaxation; in fact, it would exacerbate it.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Neostigmine is the preferred agent for reversing the effects of non-depolarizing muscle relaxants postoperatively.

questions.text: Glycopyrrolate is used as a preanesthetic agent for?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Reducing the secretions

 

  • Mechanism of Action: Glycopyrrolate is an anticholinergic agent, which means it acts by blocking the action of acetylcholine on muscarinic receptors.
  • Effect: One of the effects of this action is the reduction in the production of secretions, such as saliva and bronchial mucus.
  • Clinical Use: Given before anesthesia, it can prevent excessive secretions that might interfere with the procedure or increase the risk of aspiration. Hence, this is the primary reason glycopyrrolate is used as a preanesthetic agent.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Sedative effect: Glycopyrrolate does not have inherent sedative properties. While it may have some central side effects due to its anticholinergic action, its quaternary structure limits its ability to cross the blood-brain barrier. Thus, it doesn't produce sedation in the same manner as agents specifically designed for that purpose, like benzodiazepines.

 

Option C. Skeletal muscle relaxant: Glycopyrrolate does not have skeletal muscle relaxant properties.

 

Option D. Anxiolytic: Glycopyrrolate is not used as an anxiolytic.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Glycopyrrolate is primarily used as a preanesthetic agent to reduce secretions, thus preventing complications during anesthesia and surgery.

 

Ref: Miller’s Anesthesia, 9th Ed. Pg 849

questions.text: Identify the equipment shown in the image below?
questions.solution:
Ans. D) High flow nasal cannula

 

  • Components:
    • Flow generator: This delivers a continuous flow of medical gas, which can be up to 60 liters per minute (L/min) or more in some devices.
    • Heated humidifier: The gas is passed through a humidifier, which warms and saturates the gas with water vapor, providing near 100% humidity. This prevents mucosal drying and enhances mucociliary clearance.
    • Nasal cannula: Despite the term "nasal cannula," the prongs for HFNC are broader and shorter than traditional cannulas. They don't completely occlude the nares, allowing for the patient to breathe room air in addition to the provided gas mixture if needed.

 

Mechanism of Action:

 

  • Gas Conditioning: The humidified and warmed gas ensures better comfort and reduced airway resistance, potentially improving mucociliary function.
  • PEEP Effect: The high flow rates create a degree of positive end-expiratory pressure (PEEP) in the nasopharynx. This can be beneficial in preventing alveolar collapse and can recruit alveoli, improving oxygenation.
  • Enhanced CO2 Washout: HFNC reduces the anatomical dead space in the nasopharynx, aiding in more efficient removal of carbon dioxide.
  • Continuous High Flow: The high flow rates ensure that the fraction of inspired oxygen (FiO2) is more consistent, irrespective of the patient's respiratory pattern.

 

Advantages:

 

  • Better oxygenation: By delivering higher flow rates, HFNC can achieve better and more consistent oxygenation compared to standard oxygen therapy.
  • Comfort: Patients often find HFNC more comfortable than non-invasive positive pressure ventilation masks.
  • Flexibility: Patients can eat, drink, and communicate while using HFNC.

 

Indications:

 

  • Acute hypoxemic respiratory failure: Especially if caused by conditions like pneumonia or pulmonary edema.
  • Post-extubation support: In patients at risk for reintubation.
  • During procedures: Like bronchoscopy, to maintain oxygenation.
  • In conditions like COPD and asthma: It may aid in CO2 washout.

 

Limitations and Contraindications:

 

  • Severe hypercapnic respiratory failure: HFNC doesn't provide as much ventilation support as bilevel positive airway pressure (BiPAP) or mechanical ventilation.
  • Uncooperative or unconscious patients: Due to aspiration risk.
  • Facial trauma or recent facial surgery.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Mechanical ventilator: A mechanical ventilator is a device used to support or replace spontaneous breathing. It is more complex and provides controlled ventilation through an endotracheal tube or tracheostomy.

 

Option B. Infusion pump: An infusion pump delivers fluids, such as nutrients and medications, into a patient's body in controlled amounts. It is not related to respiratory support.

 

Option C. CPAP machine: A Continuous Positive Airway Pressure (CPAP) machine delivers a continuous level of positive airway pressure to keep the airways open. It is commonly used in sleep apnea but does not provide the high flow rates and humidification characteristic of HFNC.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • High flow nasal cannula (HFNC) is a respiratory support system that delivers high flow rates of humidified and warmed oxygen, providing benefits such as improved oxygenation, patient comfort, and flexibility in use.

questions.text: A 30-year-old male patient was intubated for surgery by a final-year resident. Which of the following is the best method to confirm the position of the endotracheal tube? (NEET PG 2021)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) End-tidal CO2 concentration

 

Methods to confirm endotracheal intubation:

  • X-ray chest
  • Auscultation
  • End-tidal CO2 concentration
  • Chest rise

 

This is considered the best method to confirm ETT placement in real-time. Capnography measures the concentration of carbon dioxide (CO2) in the exhaled breath. When the ETT is correctly placed in the trachea, it will produce a waveform with a consistent and relatively high end-tidal CO2 concentration. In contrast, if the ETT is in the esophagus or there is an airway obstruction, the end-tidal CO2 concentration will be lower or absent, providing immediate feedback to the anesthesiologist.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. X-ray chest: While a chest X-ray can confirm the placement of the ETT, it is not a practical or immediate method for confirming tube placement during intubation. X-rays are typically used for confirmation after intubation.

 

Option B. Auscultation: Auscultation involves listening to breath sounds over the chest and epigastrium to assess tube placement. While it can be a useful method, it may not always be reliable, especially in noisy clinical environments, and it may not detect esophageal intubation or partial airway obstruction.

 

Option D. Chest rise: Observing chest rise can be helpful, but it is not as reliable as capnography. In some cases, chest rise may be present even if the ETT is incorrectly placed in the esophagus, especially in cases of esophageal intubation with positive-pressure ventilation.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • The gold standard for confirming ETT placement is indeed the end-tidal CO2 concentration assessed by capnography.
  • It provides real-time feedback and is considered a more reliable method compared to other options, ensuring that the ETT is correctly placed in the trachea and the patient is being ventilated effectively.

choices.text: Severe illness which is  constant threat to life

questions.text: Which of the following criteria corresponding to ASA grade III? (INICET NOVEMBER 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. D. Severe illness

 

Explanation:

 

Option D. Severe illness: The American Society of Anesthesiologists (ASA) Physical Status Classification System is used to assess and communicate a patient's pre-anesthesia medical co-morbidities. ASA grade III is defined as a patient with severe systemic disease that is not incapacitating. This means the patient has a serious illness, but it does not necessarily pose a constant threat to life, which would correspond to ASA IV.

 

Other Options:

 

 Option A. Mild illness: This corresponds to ASA II, which is defined as a patient with mild systemic disease. It does not reach the severity required for ASA III.

 

Option B. Moderate illness: This is not an official ASA classification term. The closest would be ASA II (mild systemic disease) or ASA III (severe systemic disease).

 

Option C. Severe illness which is a constant threat to life: This corresponds to ASA IV. It describes a patient with severe systemic disease that poses a constant threat to life, not ASA III.

 

Educational Objective:

 

ASA grade III corresponds to a patient with severe systemic disease that is not incapacitating.

 

The classification system is as follows:

 

  1. ASA I: A normal healthy patient.
  2. ASA II: A patient with mild systemic disease.
  3. ASA III: A patient with severe systemic disease that is not incapacitating.
  4. ASA IV: A patient with severe systemic disease that is a constant threat to life.
  5. ASA V: A moribund patient who is not expected to survive without the operation.
  6. ASA VI: A declared brain-dead patient whose organs are being removed for donor purposes.

choices.text: Assess the patient's response, Activate ERS, check carotid pulse, Start CPR
Check carotid pulse, Start CPR, call for help and activate ERS, Defibrillate
Defibrillate, assess response, check carotid pulse, Maintain airway
Start CPR, Activate ERS, Defibrillate, Check pulse

questions.text: Which of the following is the correct sequence for CPR in Basic life support?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Assess the patient's response, Activate ERS, check carotid pulse, Start CPR

 

The American Heart Association (AHA) provides guidelines for BLS as part of its Advanced Cardiac Life Support (ACLS) recommendations. Here are the core steps of BLS as per the latest AHA guidelines :

 

1. Scene Safety: Before you start, ensure that the scene is safe for both the patient and the rescuer.

 

2. Check Responsiveness: Gently tap the patient and shout, "Are you okay?" to determine if the patient is responsive.

 

3. Activate the Emergency Response System: If the person is unresponsive, call for help or have someone else call emergency services (like 911 in the U.S.) and get an automated external defibrillator (AED) if available.

 

4. Check Breathing and Pulse Simultaneously: Look for normal breathing while checking for a pulse. If the person isn't breathing or is only gasping and has no pulse, begin CPR.

 

5. CPR (Cardiopulmonary Resuscitation):

 

  • Compressions: Start with chest compressions. Place the heel of one hand on the center of the chest and the other hand on top, interlocking the fingers. Compress the chest hard and fast, at a depth of at least 2 inches (5 cm) for adults, at a rate of 100-120 compressions per minute. Allow complete chest recoil after each compression.

  • Airway: After every 30 compressions, open the airway using a head-tilt-chin-lift maneuver.

  • Breathing: Give 2 rescue breaths after 30 compressions. Make sure there's a good seal with the patient's mouth and give a breath over one second that makes the chest rise visibly. If the chest doesn't rise, reposition the head and try again.

 

6. AED Use: As soon as an AED is available, turn it on and follow its prompts. Apply the pads and allow the AED to analyze the rhythm. If a shockable rhythm is detected, make sure no one is touching the patient and deliver the shock. Immediately resume chest compressions after the shock.

 

7. Continue CPR: Keep going with CPR (30 compressions:2 breaths) until emergency medical help arrives, the person starts to show signs of life (like breathing), the scene becomes unsafe, or the rescuer is too exhausted to continue.

 

Educational Objective : Assess the patient's response, Activate ERS, check carotid pulse, Start CPR is the correct sequence in Basic life support.

 

Ref: Miller’s Anesthesia, 9th Ed. Pgs 2715-2716

questions.text: Which is not an obvious advantage of high-flow nasal cannula? (AIIMS May 2019)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Decreases need of intubation

 

Explanation:

 

 

  • Decreases need of intubation: While high-flow nasal cannula (HFNC) can be an intermediate step between standard oxygen therapy and more invasive respiratory support, it doesn't always eliminate the need for intubation. HFNC can improve oxygenation and reduce the work of breathing in many patients, but it may not be sufficient in cases of severe respiratory failure where intubation becomes necessary.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Reduces nasopharyngeal dead space: High-flow nasal cannula allows for the delivery of oxygen at much higher flow rates than standard nasal cannulae. This higher flow rate can flush out the nasopharyngeal dead space, leading to a more consistent fraction of inspired oxygen (FiO2) and improving alveolar ventilation.

 

Option C. Heating and humidification: One of the distinct features of HFNC systems is that they deliver oxygen that's both heated and humidified. This enhances comfort, reduces the risk of mucosal drying and injury, and can help improve mucociliary clearance.

 

Option D. PEEP (Positive End-Expiratory Pressure): PEEP refers to the maintenance of a positive pressure in the airways at the end of expiration, which can prevent alveolar collapse. The high flow rate from HFNC can generate a degree of PEEP, especially with the mouth closed. This can help recruit alveoli and improve oxygenation in certain patients.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • While high-flow nasal cannula (HFNC) offers several advantages, including reducing nasopharyngeal dead space, providing heated and humidified oxygen, and generating PEEP, it does not always eliminate the need for intubation in patients with severe respiratory failure.

questions.text: How long should elective surgery be deferred for a patient who had cough and fever, after he has recovered from COVID-19, and has not required any hospitalization?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) 6 weeks

 

Elective surgery deferral based on respiratory disease severity and COVID-19 recovery:

 

  • 4 weeks: For an asymptomatic patient with mild respiratory symptoms.
  • 6 weeks: For a symptomatic patient who did not need hospital treatment.
  • 8 weeks: For a symptomatic patient who was hospitalized in the ward.
  • 12 weeks: For a patient who was admitted to the intensive care unit due to respiratory infection.

 

Application:

 

  • As this patient was symptomatic but did not need hospitalization, elective surgery can be deferred for 6 weeks.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. 8-10 weeks: This timeline is recommended for symptomatic patients who were hospitalized in the ward, which does not apply to this patient.

 

Option C. 12 weeks: This timeline is for patients who were admitted to the intensive care unit due to a respiratory infection, which also does not apply to this patient.

 

Option D. 4 weeks: This timeline is for asymptomatic patients with mild respiratory symptoms, which is not the case for this patient.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Elective surgery should be deferred for 6 weeks in a patient who had cough and fever due to COVID-19 but did not require hospitalization. This ensures sufficient recovery time to reduce perioperative risks.

 

Ref: Miller’s Anesthesia, 9th Ed. Pg 2423

questions.text: Which of these is used for immediate reversal of Vecuronium in a patient for normal kidney function? (NEET PG 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Sugammadex

 

Sugammadex is a selective relaxant binding agent / cyclodextrin molecule used to reverse the effects of certain non-depolarizing neuromuscular blocking agents, particularly rocuronium and vecuronium. It works by encapsulating the vecuronium molecule, thereby rendering it inactive and allowing for rapid reversal of muscle paralysis. Sugammadex is particularly advantageous in cases where quick recovery from neuromuscular blockade is required, and it is effective in patients with normal kidney function.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Physostigmine: Physostigmine is a cholinesterase inhibitor used primarily to reverse the effects of anticholinergic toxicity. It is not used to reverse neuromuscular blockade caused by vecuronium.

 

Option C. Rivastigmine: Rivastigmine is a cholinesterase inhibitor used in the treatment of Alzheimer's disease and other forms of dementia. It has no role in reversing neuromuscular blockade.

 

Option D. Succinylcholine: Succinylcholine is a depolarizing muscle relaxant used to induce short-term paralysis, typically for intubation. It is not used to reverse the effects of non-depolarizing neuromuscular blockers like vecuronium; rather, it is itself a paralytic agent.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Sugammadex is the drug of choice for the immediate reversal of vecuronium-induced neuromuscular blockade

choices.text: Central line insertion
Arterial line insertion

questions.text: The given set of instruments are used in? (INICET Nov 2020)
questions.solution:
Ans. C. Airway management

 

Explanation:

 

The instruments shown in the image are part of an airway cart. The equipment typically found in an airway cart is designed for managing the airway during anesthesia or in emergency situations. The contents of the airway cart usually include:

 

  • Laryngoscope: A device used to obtain a view of the vocal folds and the glottis, which is essential for endotracheal intubation.
  • Tracheal tubes of various sizes: These tubes are used to secure the airway by passing through the trachea.
  • Masks: Various types of masks to deliver oxygen or anesthetic gases.
  • Laryngeal mask airways (LMA): A device placed over the laryngeal inlet to provide ventilation.
  • Flexible fiberoptic intubation equipment: Used for intubation in difficult airway situations.
  • Retrograde intubation equipment: Tools used for intubation when conventional methods fail.
  • Front of neck access equipment: Devices for surgical airway access.
  • Equipment required for emergency invasive airway access: Tools needed for emergency tracheostomy or cricothyrotomy.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Central line insertion: This procedure requires different instruments such as central venous catheters, guidewires, dilators, and sterile drapes.

 

Option B. Arterial line insertion: This involves the use of arterial catheters, guidewires, and transducers, not typically found in an airway cart.

 

Option D. Cardiopulmonary resuscitation (CPR): CPR primarily requires defibrillators, chest compression devices, and basic airway management tools like bag-valve masks (BVM), but not the comprehensive set shown for airway management.

 

Educational Objective :

 

The instruments in an airway cart are specifically designed for various procedures involved in airway management, including intubation and emergency airway access.

choices.text: Unconsciousness with pulse and breathing absent
Unconsciousness with pulse present and breathing absent
Unconsciousness with pulse and breathing present
Unconsciousness with pulse absent and breathing present

questions.text: During resuscitation, when is the given position? (NEET PG 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Unconsciousness with pulse and breathing present

 

This is the recovery position, indicated in post-op patients who are awake or drowsy or unconscious with pulse and breathing present to prevent aspiration of any secretions or vomit.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Unconsciousness with pulse and breathing absent: Means the patient is in cardiac arrest and requires immediate resuscitation measures.

 

Option B. Unconsciousness with pulse present and breathing absent: This is respiratory arrest and rescue breathing or bag-valve-mask ventilation should be initiated to maintain breathing of patient.

 

Option D. Unconsciousness with pulse absent and breathing present: This seems very theoretical because with a lack of circulation, breathing isn’t feasible.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The recovery position is used for an unconscious patient who has a pulse and is breathing to prevent aspiration and maintain airway patency.

choices.text: FEV1 < 0.85 and FEV1/FVC <0.8
FEV1 < 0.85 and FEV1/FVC <0.75
FEV1 < 0.8 and FEV1/FVC <0.7
FEV1 < 0.8 and FEV1/FVC <0.75

questions.text:
A 60-year-old male patient has grade III ASA. Which of the following post bronchodilator PFT findings requires further evaluation of the lung function of the patient? (INICET Nov 2021)

ASA- American Society of Anesthesiology

PFT- Pulmonary function test

FEV1 - Forced expiratory volume in 1 second

FVC- Forced vital capacity
questions.solution:
Ans. C. FEV1 < 0.8 and FEV1/FVC <0.7

 

This option shows a significant reduction in both FEV1 and the FEV1/FVC ratio. An FEV1/FVC ratio of less than 0.7 is a clear indicator of obstructive lung disease. Combined with the reduced FEV1, this suggests significant lung dysfunction that requires further evaluation.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. FEV1 < 0.85 and FEV1/FVC <0.8: While these values indicate some reduction in lung function, they do not meet the threshold for a definitive diagnosis of obstructive lung disease. The FEV1/FVC ratio is still above the critical cutoff of 0.7.

 

Option B. FEV1 < 0.85 and FEV1/FVC <0.75: These values suggest reduced lung function but not to the extent that is indicative of moderate or severe COPD. The FEV1/FVC ratio is below 0.8 but not yet at the critical threshold of 0.7.

 

Option D. FEV1 < 0.8 and FEV1/FVC <0.75: While the FEV1 is below 0.8, the FEV1/FVC ratio is not at the critical threshold of 0.7, so it does not indicate significant obstructive lung disease requiring further evaluation.

 

Educational Objective :

 

As per GOLD criteria for COPD, FEV1 <0.8 and FEV1/FVC <0.7 are classified as moderate COPD and require further evaluation of lung function.

 

GOLD criteria for COPD is given as follows:

 

 

Abbreviations: COPD, chronic obstructive pulmonary disease; GOLD, Global Initiative for Lung Disease

 

As per GOLD criteria for COPD, FEV1 <0.8 and FEV1/FVC <0.7 are classified as moderate COPD and require further evaluation of the lung function.

 

Ref: Miller’s Anesthesia, 9th Ed. Pg 950

choices.text: EMLA means equal mixture of LA
Methemoglobinemia is a complication of this cream
1 gm of 5% cream contains lignocaine 50mg

questions.text: Which of these is true regarding this? (NEET PG 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Methemoglobinemia is a complication of this cream 

 

The cream shown in the image is EMLA cream, which is a topical anesthetic. EMLA cream contains a combination of two local anesthetics, lidocaine and prilocaine, in a 1:1 ratio. One of the known complications of EMLA cream is methemoglobinemia. This condition can occur, especially when the cream is used in large quantities or in patients with certain predispositions.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. EMLA means equal mixture of LA: EMLA means Eutectic mixture of LA and not equal mixture of LA.

 

Option B. It contains lignocaine and ropivacaine: This option is incorrect because EMLA cream does not contain ropivacaine. The active ingredients in EMLA cream are lidocaine (lignocaine) and prilocaine.

 

Option D. 1 gm of 5% cream contains lignocaine 50mg: This option is also incorrect. 1 gram of EMLA 5% cream contains 25mg of lidocaine and 25mg of prilocaine, not 50mg of lidocaine.

 

Educational Objective:

 

EMLA cream can cause methemoglobinemia as a complication, especially when used inappropriately or in large quantities.

questions.text:
Which of these are the components of high-quality CPR? (INICET MAY 2024)

 

a) Compression rate 100-120/min

b) Depth of compression in adults is 3-4 cm

c) Ventilation of 2 breaths for every 30 compressions

d) Allow complete chest recoil
questions.solution:
Ans. D) a, c & d

 

High-quality CPR in adults requires several critical components to be effective. These include:

 

a. Compression Rate: The compression rate should be between 100-120 compressions per minute. This rate is optimal to maintain blood flow during cardiac arrest.

 

b. Depth of Compression: For adults, the correct depth of compression is at least 2 inches (approximately 5 cm). The depth mentioned in the option B (3-4 cm) is incorrect as it is insufficient to generate adequate blood flow.

 

c. Ventilation: The recommended ventilation ratio is 2 breaths for every 30 compressions if no advanced airway is in place. This ensures adequate oxygenation during CPR.

 

d. Chest Recoil: Allowing complete chest recoil after each compression is essential. This allows the heart to refill with blood between compressions, which is crucial for effective circulation.

 

Educational Objective:

 

For high-quality CPR in adults, ensure a compression rate of 100-120/min, a compression depth of at least 2 inches (5 cm), a ventilation ratio of 30:2, and allow complete chest recoil between compressions.

questions.text: AMBU AURA40 is what generation LMA? (INICET NOV 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) First

 

AMBU AURA40 is a first-generation LMA because:

 

  • It has only one tube (the airway tube)
  • No separate gastric drainage channel
  • It is essentially a modified version of the classic LMA
  • The number "40" in its name indicates it can be used up to 40 times
  • It is unlike second-generation LMAs like Ambu AuraGain which have two tubes (airway and gastric drainage)

 



Educational Objective:

 

AMBU AURA40 is a first-generation LMA characterized by having only one tube for airway management without a separate gastric drainage channel.

 

Laryngeal Mask Airway (LMA) Generations

questions.text: Which of the following is not a contraindication to the use of morphine? (AIIMS Nov 2018)
questions.solution:
Ans. D. Acute myocardial infarction

 

Explanation:

 

Acute myocardial infarction: Morphine is often used in the setting of acute myocardial infarction (AMI) to relieve pain and anxiety. It also has the beneficial effect of reducing preload and afterload on the heart, which can decrease myocardial oxygen demand. This makes it beneficial in the management of AMI. It's not a contraindication.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Bronchial asthma: Morphine can induce histamine release, which may lead to bronchospasm. In patients with bronchial asthma, this bronchospasm can exacerbate respiratory difficulties, making morphine potentially dangerous for these patients.

 

Option B. Renal failure: Morphine is metabolized in the liver and its metabolites, especially morphine-6-glucuronide, are excreted by the kidneys. In the case of renal failure, these active metabolites can accumulate, leading to prolonged and potentially toxic effects.

 

Option C. Emphysema: Morphine has a depressive effect on the respiratory center in the brain, leading to respiratory depression. In patients with emphysema, a condition already characterized by compromised respiratory function, morphine can exacerbate respiratory difficulties and decrease the drive to breathe.

 

Educational Objective :

 

Morphine is beneficial and not contraindicated in the management of acute myocardial infarction (AMI) as it helps to relieve pain, reduce anxiety, and decrease myocardial oxygen demand.

questions.text: Which nerve is blocked in the following local anesthesia technique shown in the image below? (INICET May 2021)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Nasociliary nerve

 

  • Anatomy: The nasociliary nerve is a branch of the ophthalmic nerve, which is a branch of the trigeminal nerve (cranial nerve V).
  • Procedure: The needle is inserted 1 cm superior and 1.5 cm posterolateral to the medial canthal ligament of the eye. A maximum of 2 mL of local anesthetic solution is then slowly injected.
  • Use: This nerve block is used in procedures such as septoplasty, rhinoplasty, and the treatment of nasal bone fractures.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Anterior ethmoidal nerve: The anterior ethmoidal nerve is another branch of the ophthalmic nerve. It innervates the anterior and middle ethmoidal air cells and part of the nasal cavity, but it is not targeted by the described technique.

 

Option C. Sphenopalatine nerve: The sphenopalatine nerve, also known as the nasopalatine nerve, is a branch of the maxillary nerve (another branch of the trigeminal nerve). It supplies the nasal septum and the anterior part of the hard palate, but the described technique does not target this nerve.

 

Option D. Greater palatine nerve: The greater palatine nerve is also a branch of the maxillary nerve. It innervates the hard palate and the palatal gingiva, and is not targeted by the described technique.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • The nasociliary nerve block involves inserting a needle superior and posterolateral to the medial canthal ligament of the eye and injecting a local anesthetic solution. This technique is primarily used for procedures involving the nasal area, such as septoplasty, rhinoplasty, and nasal bone fracture treatment.

 

Ref: Miller’s Anesthesia, 9th Ed. Pg 2413-2414

questions.text: Which of the following local  anaesthetic causes hypertension?(INICET MAY 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Cocaine

 

Cocaine: An ester local anesthetic that is also a powerful central nervous system stimulant. One of the well-known cardiovascular effects of cocaine is hypertension, due to its potent vasoconstrictive properties.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Lignocaine: is an amide local anesthetic that is used to produce numbness during procedures and for treating various types of pain. It can cause side effects such as dizziness and low blood pressure but is not known for causing hypertension.

 

Option C. Bupivacaine: An amide local anesthetic known for its potent and long-lasting numbing effect. It can cause cardiovascular complications, but like lignocaine, it is more associated with cardiac toxicity rather than hypertension.

 

Option D. Prilocaine: Another amide local anesthetic, similar to lignocaine, and not commonly associated with causing hypertension.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Cocaine is the local anesthetic known to cause hypertension due to its vasoconstrictive effects.

questions.text: What is true about this position? (NEET PG 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Sniffing position for intubation

 

The image illustrates the "sniffing position," which is the ideal position for tracheal intubation. In this position, the patient’s head is elevated and extended at the atlanto-occipital joint, aligning the oral, pharyngeal, and laryngeal axes. This alignment facilitates a direct line of sight during laryngoscopy, making intubation easier. The sniffing position is a standard recommendation for intubating patients under general anesthesia.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Ideal position for Bougie insertion: The sniffing position is primarily recognized for its role in enhancing the view during direct laryngoscopy.

 

Option C. Ideal position for Neurosurgery: This option is incorrect because the sniffing position is not typically used for neurosurgical procedures. Neurosurgery often requires specific head and neck positioning to optimize access to the brain or spine, which differs from the sniffing position.

 

Option D. Neck position for intubation: The term "neck position for intubation" is too vague. The correct terminology for the position depicted in the image is the "sniffing position," which specifically describes the head and neck alignment optimal for intubation.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The sniffing position aligns the oral, pharyngeal, and laryngeal axes, making it the ideal position for tracheal intubation

choices.text: O2 pressure in inhaled air

questions.text: You are in the operating room and notice the tracing in gray color waveform on this device. What does it indicate? (INICET May 2021)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Capnography

 

  • Function: Capnography measures the concentration of CO2 in exhaled air over time, producing a waveform called a capnogram.
  • Components: Capnography equipment typically comprises a CO2 sensor, which can be placed in the circuit of a mechanically ventilated patient or near the patient's airway for non-intubated individuals (e.g., during procedural sedation). The CO2 concentration is then plotted over time to produce a waveform.
  • Waveform Analysis: The capnogram is typically divided into four phases:
    • Phase I: Baseline, representing inspired gas, which is ideally CO2-free.
    • Phase II: The expiratory upstroke, representing the beginning of expiration with a mix of dead space and alveolar gas.
    • Phase III: Alveolar plateau, where the CO2 concentration stabilizes, reflecting primarily alveolar gas.
    • Phase 0: Inspiratory downstroke, as the patient begins to inhale again.

 

 

  • End-Tidal CO2 (EtCO2): This is the maximum value of CO2 at the end of expiration, and it provides an estimation of the arterial CO2 concentration, although they may not always be identical due to various physiological and pathological factors.

 

Clinical Applications:

 

  • Confirming correct endotracheal tube placement.
  • Monitoring the quality of cardiopulmonary resuscitation (CPR). A sudden rise in EtCO2 can indicate return of spontaneous circulation (ROSC).
  • Evaluating a patient's ventilatory status.
  • Monitoring patients during procedural sedation.
  • Detecting conditions like pulmonary embolism, bronchospasm, and hypoventilation, among others.

 

Limitations:

 

  • Factors like changes in cardiac output, changes in alveolar ventilation, and equipment issues can influence the accuracy of capnography.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Airway pressure: Airway pressure monitoring involves measuring the pressure within the airways, typically during mechanical ventilation, but it does not produce a CO2 waveform.

 

Option C. O2 pressure in inhaled air: Measuring the pressure of oxygen in inhaled air is not typically displayed as a capnography waveform.

 

Option D. O2 pressure in exhaled air: Measuring the pressure of oxygen in exhaled air is not typically displayed as a capnography waveform.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Capnography is a crucial monitoring tool in the operating room and other clinical settings, used to measure and display the concentration of CO2 in exhaled air over time, helping to assess ventilation, confirm endotracheal tube placement, and monitor the effectiveness of resuscitation

questions.text: A child presents with acute respiratory distress. On examination, the abdomen was scaphoid. Which of the  following should not be performed in this patient : (INICET NOVEMBER 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. B. Bag and mask ventilation

 

Explanation:

 

Bag and mask ventilation is typically the first step in managing respiratory distress to provide support. However, in the case of a scaphoid abdomen, which suggests the possibility of a congenital diaphragmatic hernia, this method can be dangerous. It could inflate the stomach and intestines, which may be in the thoracic cavity, thus reducing lung volume further and potentially worsening respiratory distress. Therefore, bag and mask ventilation should be avoided in this scenario.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. PPV with ETT: Although this can be cautiously used, it should be carefully monitored due to the risk of increasing thoracic pressure.

 

Option C. Oxygen therapy: This is a safe method to improve oxygenation without the risks associated with positive pressure ventilation.

 

Option D. Intubation: This is necessary for securing the airway and providing ventilatory support in severe respiratory distress and is safer compared to bag and mask ventilation in the context of a suspected diaphragmatic hernia.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Bag and mask ventilation should be avoided in a child with acute respiratory distress and a scaphoid abdomen, as it may exacerbate the condition if a congenital diaphragmatic hernia is present.

questions.text: During resuscitation in a patient with severe hypotension and cardiac arrhythmias, a patient received a 20% Intralipid injection. What could have been the most probable diagnosis? (INICET Nov 2021)
questions.solution:
Ans. A. Local anesthesia toxicity

 

Intralipid (20% lipid emulsion) is used as a treatment for local anesthetic systemic toxicity (LAST). If a patient accidentally receives an excessive dose of local anesthetic, or if the local anesthetic is inadvertently injected into a blood vessel, it can lead to systemic toxicity, manifesting as CNS symptoms (like seizures) and cardiovascular collapse. Intralipid acts as a lipid sink, effectively reducing the concentration of the local anesthetic in the plasma and thereby reversing the toxic effects. This is why this option is the correct answer.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Asphyxia due to drowning: While drowning can certainly lead to hypotension and arrhythmias, it does so because of hypoxia and other related complications. Intralipid injection is not a recognized treatment for drowning and its consequences.

 

Option C. Electrocution: While electrocution can cause cardiac arrhythmias and other cardiac problems, the primary treatment is to address the rhythm disturbances directly, treat burns, and support the patient. Intralipid would not be used in this context.

 

Option D. Pulseless electrical activity (PEA): PEA refers to a condition where there is organized or semi-organized electrical activity in the heart (seen on EKG) but no palpable pulse. The treatment for PEA is high-quality CPR, following the advanced cardiac life support (ACLS) algorithm, and addressing any potential reversible causes. Intralipid is not a standard treatment for PEA.

 

Educational Objective :

 

Intralipid (20% lipid emulsion) is used specifically for treating local anesthetic systemic toxicity (LAST) by acting as a lipid sink to reduce the concentration of the local anesthetic in the plasma.

 

Ref: Miller’s Anesthesia, 9th Ed. Pg 885

choices.text: Give shock with 2 J/kg and check pulse
Give shock with 2 J/kg and continue CPR for 2 mins
Continue CPR till pulse is back

questions.text: A 2-year-old child is undergoing CPR. He is pulseless and shows the below ECG. What is the next step? (NEET PG 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Give shock with 2 J/kg and continue CPR for 2 mins

 

The ECG shown in the image is indicative of ventricular tachycardia . Pulseless VT is a life-threatening condition that requires immediate defibrillation. The appropriate treatment for VT during CPR is to deliver an unsynchronized shock (defibrillation) at an initial dose of 2 J/kg. After delivering the shock, it is crucial to immediately resume CPR for 2 minutes before reassessing the rhythm and pulse, as this maximizes the chances of successful resuscitation.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Give shock with 2 J/kg and check pulse: This option is incorrect because checking the pulse immediately after delivering the shock wastes valuable time. The correct protocol is to immediately resume CPR after the shock, without pausing to check the pulse, as this enhances the likelihood of restoring circulation.

 

Option C. Synchronized cardioversion: Synchronized cardioversion is used for treating certain types of arrhythmias, such as supraventricular tachycardia (SVT) or atrial fibrillation (AF), but it is not appropriate for pulseless ventricular tachycardia. In pulseless VT , unsynchronized defibrillation is required.

 

Option D. Continue CPR till pulse is back: This option is partially correct but incomplete. While continuing CPR is essential, the most crucial intervention in the case of pulseless VT is defibrillation. Without delivering a shock, the chances of survival are significantly diminished.

 

Educational Objective: 

 

In a pediatric cardiac arrest with pulseless ventricular tachycardia on the ECG, the correct immediate action is to defibrillate with 2 J/kg and continue CPR for 2 minutes before reassessing.

questions.text: What condition can lead to the characteristic waveform on capnography displayed by a patient under general anesthesia as observed on the ET CO2 monitor? (INICET May 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Bronchospasm

 

Shark Fin appearance seen in bronchospasm due to anaphylaxis.

 

Other options:

 

Option A. Malignant hyperthermia:

 

 

Option C. Rebreathing:

 

 

Option D. Accidental extubation

 

 

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Shark Fin appearance seen in bronchospasm is due to anaphylaxis.

questions.text: Which inhaled anesthetic agent is preferred for pediatric induction of anesthesia? (INICET MAY 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Sevoflurane

 

Sevoflurane is the preferred inhaled anesthetic agent for the induction of anesthesia in pediatric patients. This is primarily due to its pleasant, sweet smell, which makes it more tolerable for children to inhale. Additionally, Sevoflurane has a rapid onset of action, meaning it works quickly to induce anesthesia. This quick induction is critical in pediatric patients who often do not have an intravenous (IV) line placed before induction. The ability to induce anesthesia effectively and without distress is a significant advantage in this age group.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Desflurane: Desflurane is not preferred for pediatric induction because it has a pungent odor, which can be irritating and unpleasant for children. Moreover, it can cause airway irritation, which is undesirable during induction.

 

Option C. Isoflurane: While Isoflurane is effective as an anesthetic, it also has a pungent smell and slower onset of action compared to Sevoflurane, making it less ideal for pediatric use.

 

Option D. Halothane: Halothane was previously used for pediatric induction, but it has largely fallen out of favor due to its potential for causing liver toxicity and its slower onset of action compared to Sevoflurane.

 

Educational Objective:


Sevoflurane is the anesthetic agent of choice for inhalational induction in pediatric patients due to its sweet smell and rapid onset of action.

questions.text: Relieving pressure of pop off valve in this device is? (NEET PG 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) 30-40 cm H2O 

 

The image shows an Ambu bag, which is used to provide positive pressure ventilation to patients. The pop-off valve, also known as a pressure release valve, is a safety feature that prevents the delivery of excessive pressure to the patient's lungs. This valve is typically set to relieve pressure at 30-40 cm H2O, which is sufficient to ventilate the patient without causing barotrauma, which is damage to the lungs from excessive pressure.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The pop-off valve in a manual resuscitator is typically set to relieve pressure at 30-40 cm H2O to ensure safe and effective ventilation without causing lung damage.

questions.text: What is the frequency of tetanic stimulation used in neuromuscular monitoring? (INICET Nov 2021)
questions.solution:
Ans. D. 50 Hz

 

Explanation:

 

This is the frequency typically used for tetanic stimulation in neuromuscular monitoring. A stimulation of 50 Hz for 5 seconds results in a tetanic contraction. If the patient is under profound neuromuscular blockade, no contraction will be observed. If there's some recovery from blockade, a contraction will be noted but may be weaker than in a patient with no blockade. Fade during or after tetanic stimulation can indicate incomplete recovery from blockade.

 

Tetanic stimulation is a method used in neuromuscular monitoring to assess the degree of neuromuscular blockade in patients who have received neuromuscular blocking agents (often used during surgeries to produce muscle paralysis). Tetanic stimulation involves giving a high-frequency series of electrical impulses to a peripheral nerve to cause sustained muscle contraction. The response to tetanic stimulation can help determine the depth of neuromuscular blockade and the presence of fade.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. 0.2 Hz: This frequency is more representative of a "single twitch" stimulation, where one stimulus is delivered every 5 seconds. It is used to monitor the initial onset and the later stages of recovery from neuromuscular blockade.

 

Option B. 2 Hz: This refers to a train-of-four (TOF) stimulation where four stimuli are given at a frequency of 2 Hz (2 stimuli per second). It's a common method of monitoring neuromuscular blockade, especially when assessing for residual blockade. A fading response in the TOF is indicative of neuromuscular blockade.

 

Option C. 20 Hz: This isn't a standard frequency for neuromuscular monitoring.

 

Educational Objective :

 

The frequency of tetanic stimulation used in neuromuscular monitoring is typically 50 Hz.

 

 

PATTERN OF NERVE STIMULATION:

 

 

Ref: Miller’s Anesthesia, 9th Ed. Pg 1359

questions.text: Jackson Rees circuit is used in: (INICET NOV 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Pediatric controlled ventilation

 

Jackson Rees circuit (also known as Mapleson F circuit) is specifically designed for:

 

  • Pediatric patients
  • Can be used for both spontaneous and controlled ventilation in children
  • It's a modification of the Ayre's T-piece with an open-ended bag
  • This circuit is ideal for pediatric anesthesia due to its low resistance and minimal dead space

 

 

Other Options: 

 

Option B. Adult controlled ventilation: Not appropriate as Jackson Rees circuit is designed for pediatric patients. Adults require circuits with larger volumes and different configurations.

 

Option C. Obstetric ventilation: Obstetric patients require specialized circuits that can deliver high flow rates and manage rapid changes in ventilation demands.

 

Option D. Cardiac patients: Cardiac patients typically require precise control over ventilation parameters, which is better achieved with more sophisticated circuits.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Jackson Rees circuit (Mapleson F) is specifically designed and used for pediatric anesthesia, suitable for both spontaneous and controlled ventilation.

questions.text: Arrange the following anaethesia agents on the basis of their potency.(INICET MAY 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Methoxyflurane>Halothane>Isoflurane>Nitrous oxide

 

Explanation:

 

Potency of Anesthetic Agents:

  • The potency of inhaled anesthetic agents is measured by their Minimum Alveolar Concentration (MAC). The MAC value is inversely proportional to the potency; lower MAC values indicate higher potency.

 

MAC Values:

  • Methoxyflurane: 0.16
